row.entry: These rules govern the procedure for making and defending cross-claims.
These provisions set out the requirements for service of cross-claims on current parties as well as on the new parties to the proceedings.

These rules govern the conduct of proceedings on a cross-claim generally. They permit orders for the separate determination of the cross-claim, subject to a prohibition on enforcement of contribution claims before determination of the principal claim.
This Part applies to all courts in ScheduleÂ 1 of the CP Act: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The Part has the same effect as the former SCR Part 6, DCR Part 20 and LCR Part 18, except that it eliminates the third party notice procedure in the Local Court. The Part complements s 22 of the CP Act, which was itself derived from s 78 of the SCA.
Claims accrued after the commencement of proceedings ‥ [9.1.15]
Cross-claims after expiry of limitation period ‥ [9.1.55]
Judgment on separate claims — effect on other parties ‥ [9.10.15]
Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim ‥ [9.10.20]
Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on cheque or bill of exchange ‥ [9.10.25]
Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on mortgage debt ‥ [9.10.30]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.1] r 9.1 Making of cross-claim (cf SCR Part 6, rule 10; DCR Part 20, rule 10; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Making of cross-claim (cf SCR Part 6, rule 10; DCR Part 20, rule 10; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

p.text: A party (the cross-claimant) may make a cross-claim:
in proceedings commenced by statement of claim, within the time limited for the party to file a defence, or
in proceedings commenced by summons, before the return day specified in the summons,
or within such further time as the court may allow.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[3], effective 5 April 2007]
A cross-claim is to be made:
by statement of cross-claim, in the case of a cross-claim in proceedings commenced by statement of claim, or
by cross-summons, in the case of a cross-claim in proceedings commenced by summons.
Subject to this Part, these rules apply to a statement of cross-claim and cross-summons in the same way as they apply to a statement of claim and summons, respectively.
In any proceedings, each cross-claim is to be numbered (“first cross-claim”, “second cross-claim” and so on) in the order in which the cross-claims are filed.
For the purposes of rule 4.2(2)(d) , the identification of a document as a cross-claim must include the number given to the cross-claim under this rule.
The approved form for a Statement of Cross-claim is Form 9 . Form 10 is the approved form for a Cross-summons.

Where a plaintiff wishes to rely upon new matters, either as additional or alternative allegations, the statement of claim should generally be amended. However, there is nothing to prevent a plaintiff answering a defendant’s cross-claim by a further cross-claim: Toke v Andrews (1882) 8 QBD 428Â . At least this is so if the matters on which the proposed cross-claim is based arose after the commencement of the proceedings: Toke v Andrews, above; Aurel Forras Pty Ltd v Graham Karp Developments Pty Ltd [1975] VR 202Â . However, if they arose before the commencement of the proceedings, it is better merely to amend the statement of claim: James v Page (1888) 85 LT Jo 157; and see Renton Gibbs & Co Ltd v Neville & Co [1900] 2 QB 181Â ; Bankes v Jarvis [1903] 1 KB 549Â .

level.toc-caption: [9.1.15] Claims accrued after the commencement of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [9.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.17.

heading.title: Claims accrued after the commencement of proceedings

p.text: The claim to be set up under a cross-claim must be one that the court could have entertained as a separate action by the defendant: Williams Bros v Ed T Agius Ltd [1914] AC 510 at 522Â ; see CPA s 22(1) . The cross-claim may be contingent upon the outcome of the plaintiff’s claim. Thus, a cross-claim for indemnity may be made against a third party, notwithstanding that the defendant’s own liability has not been judicially determined and is an issue between the plaintiff and the defendant: Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (1981) 147 CLR 589 at 595–6; 36 ALR 3; BC8100097Â ; Andrews v Nominal Defendant [1963] NSWR 359; [1963] SR (NSW) 110Â ; Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Turnbull & Partners Ltd (1991) 33 FCR 265 at 273; 106 ALR 115Â ; Barclays Bank v Tom [1923] 1 KB 221; [1922] All ER Rep 279Â . Apart from such instances, the cross-claim may be set up notwithstanding that the defendant has acquired the claim after the commencement of the proceedings: Beddall v Maitland (1881) 17 Ch D 174Â ; Wood v Goodwin [1884] WN 17Â ; Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals v Consolidated Press Ltd (1952) 70 WN (NSW) 232Â ; Crothers v Hire Finance Ltd (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 469Â . The right to plead a cross-claim that has accrued since the proceedings were commenced does not depend upon UCPR r 14.17 : Baldry v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 415 at 419Â .

Historically, various expressions have been used to refer to the different procedures by which a defendant could bring claims against either the plaintiff or third parties in existing proceedings. Generally speaking, the expression “counter-claim” referred to claims brought against the plaintiff, although it might also include claims against additional parties: Nelson v Council of Shire of Wyong (1989) 68 LGRA 164; (1992) Aust Torts Â¶81–177Â ; McDonnell & East Ltd v McGregor (1936) 56 CLR 50; [1936] ALR 324Â . Such a claim need not be related to the subject matter of the plaintiff’s claim: Gray v Webb (1882) 21 Ch D 802Â . “Third party” notices or claims could be brought against persons who were not originally parties to the proceedings, where the subject matter related to the original plaintiff’s claim. The difference between the procedures was not always a mere matter of terminology. Thus, even though a defendant could join a claim against a new party in a counter-claim against the original plaintiff, the new party could not bring a further counter-claim against the original defendant: Street v Gover (1877) 2 QBD 498Â . Nor could such a person counter-claim against the original plaintiff: Alcoy & Gandia Railway & Harbour Co Ltd v Greenhill [1896] 1 Ch 19Â . In the courts to which the UCPR apply, the distinction between counter-claim and third-party notice has been effectively abolished. Both types of claims must now be brought as a cross-claim.
Legislation cited in [9.1.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22(2).

Cross-claims against non-plaintiffs can only be brought where the relief claimed relates to, or is connected with, the plaintiff’s claim in the original proceedings: CPA s 22(2) ; Padwick v Scott (1876) 2 Ch D 736Â ; Turner v Hednesford Gas Co (1878) 3 Ex D 145; Dear v Sworder (1876) 4 Ch D 476Â ; Barber v Blaiberg (1882) 19 Ch D 473Â ; SF Edge Ltd v Weigel (1907) 97 LT 447Â . If the cross-claim is against both third parties and an existing plaintiff, including cases of joint liability between the proposed cross-defendants, it still requires a sufficient relationship between the cross-claim and the plaintiff’s original claim: DG Madin Ltd v Gordon [1964] SASR 64 at 66Â .
Legislation cited in [9.1.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 9.8.

Subject to the court’s power under UCPR r 9.8 , any cross-claim may be brought against the plaintiff — irrespective of whether or not it arises in connection with the plaintiff’s original claim: Gray v Webb (1882) 21 Ch D 802Â ; Re Richardson [1933] WN (Eng) 90; [1933] 175 LT Jo 269. If there are multiple plaintiffs, a defendant may cross-claim against individual plaintiffs: Manchester Sheffield & Lincolnshire Railway Co v Brooks (1877) 2 Ex D 243Â . A defendant may also cross-claim against a co-defendant who has a joint entitlement with the plaintiff: Burnside v Harrison Marks Productions Ltd [1968] 2 All ER 286Â .
Legislation cited in [9.1.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 21, sÂ 22, s 90.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.1.

Under CPA s 90 and UCPR r 36.1 , the court may give any such judgment as the nature of the case requires, irrespective of whether or not a claim for relief extending to that judgment or order is included in any originating process. Under these powers, orders may be made in favour of a defendant who has not filed a cross-claim: Graham H Roberts Pty Ltd v Maurbeth Investments Pty Ltd [1974] 1 NSWLR 93Â ; Farrell v Mulroney [1978] 1 NSWLR 221 at 224–5Â . (This sometimes occurs in proceedings for declaratory relief: Harrison-Broadley v Smith [1964] 1 All ER 867; [1964] 1 WLR 456Â ; Loudon v Ryder (No 2) [1953] Ch 423Â ; Re Maiorana and the Conveyancing Act (1970) 90 WN (NSW) 365; Graham H Roberts, above; Farrell v Mulroney, above.) The court therefore has the power to give a judgment or make an order in favour of the defendant, notwithstanding that a cross-claim has not been filed. However, the preferable course is for a defendant to file a cross-claim (even after reasons for judgment have been delivered) to ensure that the pleadings reflect all questions between the parties that were in fact finally dealt with in the proceedings. A defendant’s express entitlement to cross-claim is set out in CPA sÂ 22 . The section permits the court to grant a defendant any relief that might have been granted in separate proceedings commenced by the defendant. The power conferred is limited by the requirement that any relief granted against a person other than the original plaintiff must relate to, or be connected with, the subject matter of the original plaintiff’s claim: see CPA sÂ 22(2). Despite the apparent amplitude of its terms, the section does not remove the distinction between defences and cross-claims. All claims that are not true defences are to be pleaded as cross-claims. Whether a claim is a defence or not depends upon the substantive law: McDonnell & East Ltd v McGregor (1936) 56 CLR 50 at 56–9; [1936] ALR 324Â . A defendant’s right to set-off is partly set out in CPA sÂ 21 . Under that section, a defendant is entitled to set off mutual debts that were due and payable at the time the defence of set-off was filed. In addition, CPA s 90 permits the court to set-off judgments and enter judgment only for the balance of competing claims between the parties to the proceedings. These provisions suggest that in many instances there is not likely to be a material difference between the characterisation of a claim as one giving rise to a defence, in the strict sense, or a right of set-off. However, a matter that is properly the subject of a cross-claim can only be raised within the limitation period, and this may give rise to a point of distinction in some cases: Sidney Raper Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia [1975] 2 NSWLR 227Â ; Henriksens Rederi A/S v THZ Rolimpex (The Brede) [1974] QB 233Â .

Confusion can arise where there are multiple cross-claims and multiple parties to those cross-claims. Technically, the parties to the first cross-claim are properly described as first cross-claimant (and second cross-claimant) and first cross-defendant (and second cross-defendant). Where a second (or subsequent) cross-claim has been made, the parties' correct descriptions are first cross-claimant (and second cross-claimant) to the second cross-claim, and first cross-defendant (and second cross-defendant) to the second cross-claim. However, this method of description, while technically correct, becomes impenetrable where there are numerous cross-claims. In these cases, it is desirable to add a shorthand description at the end of the formal description of the pleading. As an example, an appropriate description may be “Defence of the second cross-defendant to the eighth cross-claim (Jones’ defence to Smith’s claim for contribution)”.
Legislation cited in [9.1.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 21.
(NSW) Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 ssÂ 5, 6, 7.

The statutory right of set-off does not preclude a defendant from relying on a defence of equitable set-off: see the notes to CPA sÂ 21 . In a court of limited equitable jurisdiction, it will be necessary to give particular attention to the nature of the claim. Although under ssÂ 5 , 6 and 7 of the Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 all inferior courts may entertain every ground of defence, equitable or legal, they do not enlarge the jurisdiction of any inferior court: United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 at 332Â ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336 at 338; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072Â per Gaudron, Gummow and Callinan JJ. Section 7 of the Act says specifically that the Act “does not enlarge” jurisdiction, and the provisions of s 5 are directed only to those courts invested with jurisdiction to administer simultaneously both law and equity: Joblin v Carney (1975) 1 BPR 9642Â .
Legislation cited in [9.1.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rrÂ 1.12, r 14.3(1), 9.1(1), rÂ 9.10.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22.

The ordinary time limited for filing a defence is “28 days after service of the statement of claim to which the defence relates”: r 14.3(1) . Thus, the ordinary position under the present rule is that a cross-claim may be filed either before the return date (in proceedings commenced by summons) or within 28 days of service of the originating statement of claim. However, both rrÂ 1.12 and 9.1(1) grant a power to extend time. Various decisions, apparently based on a restricted reading of rules similar to rÂ 9.10 , have either held or assumed that a cross-claim can only be brought while the original proceedings are on foot: The Salybia [1910] P 25Â ; The Saxicava [1924] P 131Â ; Ernst & Young v Butte Mining PLC [1996] 1 WLR 1605Â (these cases all dealt with cross claims after a plaintiff’s discontinuance); Crayford Freight Services Ltd v Coral Seatel Navigation Navigation Co (1998) 82 FCR 328; 162 ALR 119Â (cross claim irregularly filed prior to discontinuance); Shanks and Co Pty Ltd v Hohese [1963] VR 198Â (no cross claim after default judgment). But the power to entertain cross claims (conferred by CPA s 22 ) has also been held sufficient to permit a cross claim to be filed at any time before satisfaciton of the principal judgment: CSI International Co Ltd v Archway Personnel (Middle East) [1980] 3 All ER 215 at 220Â ; and see also Stott v West Yorkshire Road Car Co Ltd [1971] 2 QB 651; [1971] 3 All ER 534Â . Furthermore, both rrÂ 1.12 and 9.1(1) grant a power to extend time, and the exercise of that power has been held to permit a cross claim to be filed at any time: See UCPR rÂ 9.10 and [9.10.5] .

level.toc-caption: [9.1.55] Cross-claims after expiry of limitation period

p.text: Legislation cited in [9.1.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Limitation Act 1969 s 74.

heading.title: Cross-claims after expiry of limitation period

p.text: The time at which a cross-claim is taken to have been commenced is determined in accordance with s 74 of the Limitations Act 1969. The claim is taken to have been commenced on the earliest date on which the person against whom the claim is made became a party to the proceedings. Consequently, if the cross-claim is against the plaintiff, and the limitation period had not expired before the commencement of the proceedings, the cross-claim will necessarily be within time: O’Neill v Foster (2004) 61 NSWLR 499; [2004] NSWSC 906; BC200406789Â (trespass cross-claim against the plaintiff in Property Relationship proceedings). Where the cross-claim is brought against a third person who is also a party to the proceedings, the claim is taken to have been brought when they first became a party to the proceedings: Nelson v Wyong Shire Council (1989) 68 LGRA 164 at 167-9; (1992) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-177Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.2] r 9.2 Existing parties need not enter separate appearance

leg:heading.title: Existing parties need not enter separate appearance

p.text: A party against whom a cross-claim is made (the cross-defendant) is not required to enter an appearance if he or she:
is a party to the proceedings in which the cross-claim is made, and
has entered an appearance in those proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.3] r 9.3 Cross-claimant may rely on previous pleadings (cf SCR PartÂ 6, rule 11; DCR Part 20, rule 11; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Cross-claimant may rely on previous pleadings (cf SCR PartÂ 6, rule 11; DCR Part 20, rule 11; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

p.text: A cross-claimant may, in the cross-claim, plead all or any of the facts on which he or she relies by reference to the previous pleadings in the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises.
The cross-defendant must include in his or her defence to a statement of cross-claim any grounds on which he or she disputes the claim made by the cross-claimant.
[r 9.4 am Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 30 September 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.5] r 9.5 Default of cross-defendant to cross-claim (cf SCR PartÂ 6, ruleÂ 7; DCR Part 20, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Default of cross-defendant to cross-claim (cf SCR PartÂ 6, ruleÂ 7; DCR Part 20, rule 7)

p.text: If a cross-defendant does not file a defence to a statement of cross-claim in accordance with these rules or an order of the court:
any judgment (including summary judgment, judgment by default or judgment by consent) on any claim, question or issue in the proceedings, so far as it is relevant to the cross-claim, and

any decision (including any decision by consent) on any claim, question or issue in the proceedings, so far as it is relevant, is binding, as between the parties to the cross-claim, unless the court orders otherwise.
[r 9.5 am Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 30 September 2005]
Legislation cited in [r 9.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 PtÂ 16, rÂ 13.1.

The default of the cross-defendant gives rise to a deemed admission of the claim. If the proceedings have been commenced by a statement of claim, default judgment may be available against the cross-defendant under PtÂ 16 of the UCPR. Alternatively, a cross-claimant may apply for summary judgment under rÂ 13.1 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.6] r 9.6 Service on active parties (cf SCR Part 6, rule 5; DCR Part 20, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Service on active parties (cf SCR Part 6, rule 5; DCR Part 20, rule 5)

p.text: If a cross-defendant is an active party, personal service of a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons on that party is not required.
Rule 10.16 (Service by filing) does not apply to service of a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.7] r 9.7 Service on new parties (cf SCR Part 6, rule 5; DCR Part 20, rule 5; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Service on new parties (cf SCR Part 6, rule 5; DCR Part 20, rule 5; LCR Part 18, rule 1)

p.text: This rule applies to the service of a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons on a person who is not already a party to the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises.

When serving the statement of cross-claim or cross-summons, the cross-claimant must serve on the cross-defendant both the originating process in the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises and such of the following documents as have been filed by or served on the cross-claimant:
in proceedings commenced by statement of claim or in which a statement of claim has been filed, any other pleadings,
in proceedings commenced by summons, any other cross-summonses,
any notices of motion not finally disposed of,
any affidavits, other than affidavits that are not relevant to the questions arising on the cross-claim,
any other documents that have been served by the plaintiff on the defendant, or by the defendant on the plaintiff, and are intended to be relied on,
any amendments to any of the documents referred to in paragraphs (a)–(e).
Service of a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons must be effected in accordance with the provisions of these rules with respect to service of originating process.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.8] r 9.8 Directions (cf SCR Part 6, rule 4; DCR Part 20, rule 4; LCR PartÂ 18, ruleÂ 4)

leg:heading.title: Directions (cf SCR Part 6, rule 4; DCR Part 20, rule 4; LCR PartÂ 18, ruleÂ 4)

p.text: The court, at any stage of the proceedings:
may order that any cross-claim, or any question in or arising on any cross-claim, is to be separately tried, and
may direct generally the extent to which the usual procedures at a trial or hearing are to be modified because of the joinder of the cross-defendant.
Legislation cited in [9.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 9.10.

Normally the original claim and all cross-claims are heard together. It is only in special circumstances that separate trials should be ordered: Barclays Bank v Tom [1923] 1 KB 221; [1922] All ER Rep 279Â ; Stewart v Sydney County Council [1973] 1 NSWLR 444Â ; Standen v GH Varley Pty Ltd (1956) 56 SR (NSW) 346; Godfrey v Nominal Defendant [1963] SR (NSW) 412Â . But this general proposition assumes either that the parties are identical or that the issues are closely connected. Of course, a relevant connection between the claims is required before cross-claims can be brought, but it does not follow that all parties to the proceedings will be directly concerned in all the related issues. For example, the third party cross-defendant may be an insurer and the issue between defendant and third party may be confined to the validity of the policy. In such a case, a separate trial of the cross-claim is justified: Waters v Smith [1969] 1 NSWR 151Â ; Martin v Cassidy (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 433Â ; Australian Mutual Provident Fire & General Insurance Co Ltd v Dixon [1982] VR 833Â ; see also rÂ 9.10 of the UCPR. Alternatively, the court may dismiss the cross-claim with leave to the defendant to commence fresh proceedings if it considers it appropriate. A cross-claim in defamation will normally be so treated: South African Republic v La Compagne France-Belge Du Chemin De Fer Du Nord [1897] 2 Ch 487Â ; Wood v Cross Television Centre Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 528; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 596Â .

Ordinarily, a cross-defendant may not interrogate a plaintiff, nor one defendant his or her co-defendants, as there is no issue between them: Buxton & Lysaght Pty Ltd v Buxton [1977] 1 NSWLR 285Â . However, orders for discovery and interrogatories against a plaintiff may be made on the application of a cross-claimant where they are necessary for the proper disposal of the proceedings: Cojuanco v Routley [1983] 1 NSWLR 723Â ; Barker & Taylor Pty Ltd v Cablemakers (ACT) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 719Â ; Eden v Weardale Iron & Coal Co (1887) 35 Ch D 287Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.9] r 9.9 Proceedings to continue together (cf SCR Part 6, rule 6(1); DCR PartÂ 20, ruleÂ 6(1); LCR PartÂ 18, rule 3(1))

leg:heading.title: Proceedings to continue together (cf SCR Part 6, rule 6(1); DCR PartÂ 20, ruleÂ 6(1); LCR PartÂ 18, rule 3(1))

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, proceedings on a cross-claim are to be carried on together with the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.10] r 9.10 Cross-claim may be separately prosecuted (cf SCR Part 6, rule 8; DCR Part 20, rule 8; LCR Part 18, rule 3(5))

leg:heading.title: Cross-claim may be separately prosecuted (cf SCR Part 6, rule 8; DCR Part 20, rule 8; LCR Part 18, rule 3(5))

p.text: A cross-claim may proceed even if:
judgment has been entered on the originating process in the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises or any other cross-claim in the proceedings, or
the proceedings on the originating process or any other cross-claim have been stayed, dismissed, withdrawn or discontinued.
Proceedings on the originating process in the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises may proceed even if:
judgment has been entered on any cross-claim in the proceedings, or
the proceedings on any such cross-claim have been stayed, dismissed, withdrawn or discontinued.
Legislation cited in [9.10.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rrÂ 1.12, 9.1(1), rÂ 9.8.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 22.

The present rule supplements the court's power under rÂ 9.8 of the UCPR to give directions for the separate determination of cross-claims. It specifically authorises the continuation of proceedings on the cross-claim, notwithstanding the resolution of the plaintiff’s claim, whether tha has occurred as a result of judgment, stay, dismissal or discontinuance: Stott vÂ West Yorkshire Road Car Co Ltd [1971] 2 QB 651; [1971] 3 All ER 534; [1971] 3 WLR 282Â . The rule appears to assume that the cross-claim has been validly filed before the resolution of the principal claim, And unless difficulties arise in relation to matters such as limitation defences or the cross-defendant’s submission to jursidiction in the particular proceedings, it will often be immaterial whether a defendant’s claim is pursued by way of cross-claim or in separate proceedings.

But the discretion conferred by the present rule may also apply to a cross-claim that has been irregularly filed (eg, without leave) before the resolution of the principal claim: Crayford Freight Services Ltd vÂ Coral Seatel Navigation Co (1998) 82 FCR 328; 162 ALR 119; BC9800909Â reversing Carlton International plc & Bradmans Stores Pty Ltd vÂ Crayford Freight Services Ltd (1997) 78 FCR 302; BC9704109Â ; Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee vÂ Patrick Operations Pty Ltd (2001) 21 NSWCCR 471Â .

It can also apply to a cross-claim filed after the resolution of the plaintiff’s claim: Seltsam Pty Ltd vÂ Energy Australia (1999) 17 NSWCCR 720; [1999] NSWCA 89; BC9901424Â ; Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd vÂ Bluescope Steel Ltd [2012] NSWCA 240; BC201206206Â (claim made after judgment and all the liabilities in the principal proceedings had been satisfied by payment). In these instances, the court’s power to extend the time for filing a cross-claim (contained in rrÂ 1.12 and 9.1(1) ) permits the court to continue to act in the original proceedings: FAI General Insurance Co Ltd vÂ Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268; 77 ALR 411; 62 ALJR 216; [1988] HCA 13; BC8802594Â and the exercise of the power to extend time in those proceedings attracts the potential to determine any cross-claim that otherwise falls within CPA sÂ 22 : Seltsam Pty Ltd vÂ Energy Australia (1999) 17 NSWCCR 720; [1999] NSWCA 89; BC9901424Â .
Legislation cited in [9.10.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90(2)(b).

Under CPA s 90(2)(b) , separate judgments may be ordered on the claim and the cross-claim. Separate costs orders may also be made: McDonnell & East Ltd v McGregor (1936) 56 CLR 50 at 62; [1936] ALR 324Â ; Childs v Blacker [1954] 2 All ER 243Â ; Chell Engineering v Unit Tool and Engineering Co Ltd [1950] 1 All ER 378Â . In the absence of a special costs order, difficulties could occur in the apportionment of cost items that were common to both claim and the cross-claim: Medway Oil and Storage Co Ltd v Continental Contractors Ltd [1929] AC 88Â ; Smith v Madden (1946) 73 CLR 129; [1946] ALR 337Â .

level.toc-caption: [9.10.15] Judgment on separate claims — effect on other parties

heading.title: Judgment on separate claims — effect on other parties

p.text: A cross-defendant is bound by the result of the trial, unless a contrary order is made under CPA sÂ 22(3)(b) , and may appeal against any judgment both on the claim and on the cross-claim: Helicopter Sales (Aust) Pty Ltd v Rotor-Work Pty Ltd (1974) 132 CLR 1; 4 ALR 77Â ; Asphalt and Public Works Ltd v Indemnity Guarantee Trust Ltd [1969] 1 QB 465; [1968] 3 All ER 509Â ; Sandtara Pty Ltd v Abigroup Ltd (1997) 42 NSWLR 5Â ; Insurance Exchange of Australasia Group v Dooley (2000) 50 NSWLR 222; [2000] NSWCA 159; BC200004689Â ; James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Seltsam (1998) 196 CLR 53; 159 ALR 268; [1998] HCA 78; BC9806759Â . Consequently, a cross-defendant who seeks to defend the plaintiff’s claim by relying on points additional to those pleaded by the principal defendant, should usually be permitted to do so: Witham v Vane (1880) 49 LJ Ch 242Â ; Barclays Bank v Tom [1923] 1 KB 221; [1922] All ER Rep 279Â ; Coote v Richards [2001] 2 Qd R 20; [2000] QCA 112; BC20008522Â ; cf Crowe v Wheeler & Reynolds [1986] 2 Qd R 84Â (leave refused where plaintiff’s case closed). A cross-defendant who admits liability to indemnify the defendant may be substituted for the original defendant, at least if the plaintiff does not object: Coles v Civil Service Supply Assn (1884) 26 Ch D 529Â ; Barton v London and North Western Railway Co (1888) 38 Ch D 144Â ; Municipal Council of Sydney v Bull [1909] 1 KB 7Â ; Matthey v Curling [1922] 2 AC 180 at 198Â .

level.toc-caption: [9.10.20] Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [9.10.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 13.2.

heading.title: Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim

p.text: The court may stay execution on the plaintiff’s claim even in relation to a judgment that is apparently justified by admissions contained in the defence. Whether a stay should be granted depends upon the nature of the competing claims and the parties against whom the cross-claim has been brought. Assuming it raises a triable issue, a cross-claim may justify a stay where it claims damages for breach of the contract on which the plaintiff sues, or otherwise gives rise to a right of set-off against the plaintiff’s claim: Mersey Steamship Co v Shuttleworth (1883) 10 QBD 468Â ; affirmed in Mersey Steamship Co v Shuttleworth (1883) 11 QBD 531Â . Similarly, a defendant’s cross-claim against an insurer for indemnity in respect of the plaintiff’s claim may provide an appropriate basis for a stay. The stay may be granted either unconditionally, or on terms, until the determination of the cross-claim: Court v Sheen (1891) 7 TLR 556Â ; Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd v Miles [1958] QWN 7Â . As regards stay of summary judgment pending determination of cross-claim, see UCPR rÂ 13.2 .

level.toc-caption: [9.10.25] Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on cheque or bill of exchange

heading.title: Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on cheque or bill of exchange

p.text: Where the plaintiff claims on a bill of exchange, the existence of a cross-claim for unliquidated damages is not normally a ground for a stay of execution: Nova (Jersey) Knit Ltd v Kammgarn Spinnerei GmbH [1977] 2 All ER 463; [1977] 1 WLR 713Â ; Evershore Textiles Manufacturing Co Ltd v Webb [1978] Qd R 347Â ; Brown Shipley & Co v Alicia Hosiery [1966] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 668; James Lamont & Co Ltd v Hyland Ltd [1950] 1 KB 585Â ; John Shearer Ltd v Gehl Co (1995) 60 FCR 136; 134 ALRÂ 1; BC9501997Â (stay may be available where the bill of exchange is liable to be set aside by orders made under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010)); Ferro Corp (Aust) Pty Ltd v International Pools Australia Pty Ltd (1993) 30 NSWLR 539Â ; cf Saga of Bond St Ltd v Avalon Promotions Ltd [1972] 2 QB 325Â .

level.toc-caption: [9.10.30] Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on mortgage debt

p.text: Legislation cited in [9.10.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 39.1(1)(d).

heading.title: Stay of judgment on plaintiff’s claim — none where based on mortgage debt

p.text: Similarly, a cross-claim for damages will not generally provide a basis for a stay of execution of a judgment for possession based on non-payment of an amount due under a mortgage: Australia & New Zealand Bank Ltd v Squires (NSWSC, Lusher J, 23 August 1982, unreported); affirmed by Court of Appeal, 6 December 1982; even where the cross-claim is asserted by way of equitable set off: National Westminster Bank Plc v Skelton [1993] 1 All ER 242; [1993] 1 WLR 72Â ; Horrobin v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 89 at 100; BC9604330Â ; cf Derham Set-Off, 2nd ed, para [1.7.13] and the cases there cited. However, a judgment for possession cannot be enforced without leave to issue a writ for possession under UCPR rÂ 39.1(1)(d) , and the court may withhold leave or order that the execution of the writ be stayed: State Bank of New South Wales v Boolangatta Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Waddell CJ, 9 August 1989, unreported).
Legislation cited in [9.10.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90(2)(a).

Under CPA s 90(2)(a) , where there is a claim and cross-claim, the court may give judgment for the balance only of the sums of money awarded on the respective claims, or give judgment in respect of each claim. The provision to offset claims in this manner is similar to rules in many jurisdictions which specifically permit the court to set-off judgments and to give a single judgment for the balance in favour of the successful party. There is authority for the view that, even in the absence of such a provision, the court has power to order that one judgment be set-off against another: Ryan v South Sydney Junior Rugby League Club Ltd [1975] 2 NSWLR 660Â ; Bank of New South Wales v Preston (1894) 20 VLR 1Â ; Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Clarke JA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215), approving Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWSC, Young J, 3748/89, 12 December 1994, unreported, BC9403409) (set-off of costs orders).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 9.11] r 9.11 Contribution or indemnity (cf SCR Part 6, ruleÂ 9; DCR PartÂ 20, ruleÂ 9; LCR Part 19, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Contribution or indemnity (cf SCR Part 6, ruleÂ 9; DCR PartÂ 20, ruleÂ 9; LCR Part 19, rule 1)

p.text: If a defendant makes a cross-claim for contribution or indemnity in respect of a claim made against the defendant in the proceedings, judgment on the cross-claim:
is not to be entered except by leave of the court, and
is not to be enforced until any judgment in the proceedings against the defendant has been satisfied.

If a cross-claim in any proceedings includes a claim for contribution under section 5 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 in respect of a claim made in the proceedings against the party by whom it is filed, a defence to the cross-claim, or subsequent pleadings on the cross-claim, may not be filed unless the court so directs.

Under this rule, formal judgment on a cross-claim for indemnity or contribution cannot be obtained before judgment has been entered in the action between the plaintiff and the defendant. Leave will be given after judgment in the main action or in cases where there is a distinct indemnity upon a special agreement: English and Scottish Trust Co v Flatou (1888) 36 WR 238.
